conclusion: The problem involves finding the magnitude of the voltage \( U \) across the resistor \( R \) and the direction of the induced current flowing through the resistor.

The setup consists of two parallel guide rails \( ab \) and \( cd \) separated by a distance \( l \), with a resistor \( R \) connected between \( b \) and \( d \). A conductor rod \( MN \) is placed on the rails, moving uniformly to the right at speed \( v \) in a uniform magnetic field \( B \) pointing into the paper.
The magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of the guide rails, and the resistance of the guide rails is negligible.
The force applied to the conductor \( MN \) is uniform and directed towards the right.
The force \( F \) on the conductor \( MN \) is given by \( F = B \cdot I \cdot v \), where \( I \) is the current in the conductor.
The current \( I \) in the conductor is given by \( I = \frac{U}{R} \), where \( U \) is the voltage across the resistor.
The voltage \( U \) across the resistor is given by \( U = IR \).
Since the force \( F \) is directed towards the right, the current \( I \) must also be directed towards the right.
The direction of the induced current is towards the right.
Substituting the expression for \( I \) into \( U = IR \), the magnitude of the voltage \( U \) is constant because \( R \) is constant.
The magnitude of the voltage \( U \) across the resistor \( R \) is \( IR \), and the direction of the induced current flowing through the resistor \( R \) is towards the right.
